prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Planetary Mass Companions in Taurus
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe two planetary mass companions in Taurus in 230 GHz dust continuum and CO (2-1) to search for evidence of a circumplanetary disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect and measure dust continuum from disks around these planetary mass companions, so we dedicate three of our basebands to detecting dust continuum emission. We would, however, also like to search for the presence of molecular gas in these disks so we request that one baseband observe in spectral line mode with a bandwidth of 468.75 MHz and ~0.3 km/s channels to search for CO 2-1. If we detect disks in CO we would like to measure Keplerian rotation and determine dynamical masses for the central planetary mass companion. CO 2-1 has previously been detected in the disk of FW Tau C with a line FWHM of 1.9 km/s (Caceres et al. 2015). We assume that CO 2-1 around our targets will have comparable line widths, so the requested 0.3 km/s resolution should be sufficient to resolve Keplerian rotation in the disk.

Studies have suggested that the disks around planetary mass companions have radii that are a third of the Hill radius for the companion (e.g. Ayliffe 2009). We calculate the Hill radius for each of our targets and find that the disks are likely very compact, with diameters of ~50 AU, or ~0.3". We use the projected separation in this calculation; if the actual separation is larger then the disks may be even more compact. We therefore select a resolution of 0.14", smaller than the estimated disk size by a factor of a few in case our estimate is an upper limit, so that we can resolve these disks and determine their sizes. Furthermore, we use the estimate of the circumplanetary disk diameter, of ~0.3", as our largest angular scale for the source. We need not be sensitive to scales larger than the estimated disk diameter.

We propose to observe every planetary mass companion which shows strong evidence for a circumplanetary disk. Kraus et al. (2015) show that the planetary mass companion FW Tau C is surrounded by an unresolved disk with a 1.3 mm flux of 1.78 mJy, implying the disk contains 1-2 Earth masses of material. Here we request sensitivity sufficient to detect disks that are 10 times fainter, containing 0.1 Earth masses of material, comparable to the amount of mass in the Moon or the Jovian satellites. We assume a characteristic dust temperature of 20 K, an opacity of 2.3 cm^2/g at 1.3 mm, a dust mass of 0.1 M_Earth, and a distance of 140 pc (characteristic of all of our sources) to infer that 0.1 Earth masses of material would have a flux of 120 micro-Jy at 1.3 mm. We wish to detect such sources with signal-to-noise of 3, so we request a sensitivity of 40 micro-Jy.
Our primary science goal is detecting the dusty disks around our targets so our sensitivity request is driven by dust continuum detection. However, Caceres et al. (2015) present a detection of CO (2-1) towards FW Tau C with a peak line flux of 70 mJy. With the integration times determined by our dust continuum calculations we will achieve an rms of ~5 mJy/beam in the requested 0.3 km/s channels which will be more than sufficient to well detect CO (2-1) towards our targets if they are comparable to FW Tau C.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect and measure dust continuum from disks around these planetary mass companions, so we dedicate three of our basebands to detecting dust continuum emission. Studies have suggested that the disks around planetary mass companions have radii that are a third of the Hill radius for the companion (e.g. Ayliffe 2009). We calculate the Hill radius for each of our targets and find that the disks are likely very compact, with diameters of ~35-50 AU, or ~0.25"-0.33". We use the projected separation in this calculation; if the actual separation is larger then the disks may be even more compact. We therefore select a resolution of 0.11", smaller than the estimated disk size by a factor of a few in case our estimate is an upper limit, so that we can resolve these disks and determine their sizes. Our primary science goal is detecting the dusty disks around our targets so our sensitivity request is driven by dust continuum detection. However, Caceres et al. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GQ Lup B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe the planetary mass companions GQ Lup B in 230 GHz dust continuum and CO (2-1) to search for evidence of a circumplanetary disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect and measure dust continuum from disks around these planetary mass companions, so we dedicate three of our basebands to detecting dust continuum emission. We would, however, also like to search for the presence of molecular gas in these disks so we request that one baseband observe in spectral line mode with a bandwidth of 468.75 MHz and ~0.3 km/s channels to search for CO 2-1. Studies have suggested that the disks around planetary mass companions have radii that are a third of the Hill radius for the companion (e.g. Ayliffe 2009). We calculate the Hill radius for our target and find that its disk is likely very compact, with a diameter of ~15 AU, or ~0.1". We use the projected separation in this calculation; if the actual separation is larger then the disk may be even more compact. We therefore select a resolution of 0.04", smaller than the estimated disk size by a factor of a few in case our estimate is an upper limit, so that we can resolve the disk and determine its size. Furthermore, we use the estimate of the circumplanetary disk diameter, of ~0.1", as our largest angular scale for the source. We need not be sensitive to scales larger than the estimated disk diameter.

We propose to observe every planetary mass companion which shows strong evidence for a circumplanetary disk. Kraus et al. Here we request sensitivity sufficient to detect disks that are 10 times fainter, containing 0.1 Earth masses of material, comparable to the amount of mass in the Moon or the Jovian satellites. Our primary science goal is detecting the dusty disks around our targets so our sensitivity request is driven by dust continuum detection. However, Caceres et al. (2015) present a detection of CO (2-1) towards FW Tau C with a peak line flux of 70 mJy. With the integration times determined by our dust continuum calculations we will achieve an rms of ~5 mJy/beam in the requested 0.3 km/s channels which will be more than sufficient to well detect CO (2-1) towards our targets if they are comparable to FW Tau C.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CT Cha B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe the planetary mass companions CT Cha B in 230 GHz dust continuum and CO (2-1) to search for evidence of a circumplanetary disk.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our primary goal is to detect and measure dust continuum from disks around these planetary mass companions, so we dedicate three of our basebands to detecting dust continuum emission. We therefore select a resolution of 0.14", smaller than the estimated disk size by a factor of a few in case our estimate is an upper limit, so that we can resolve the disk and determine its size. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In the last decade, direct imaging surveys have discovered dozens of planetary mass companions (PMCs) at ultra-wide separations from their host stars. The origin of these objects remains unclear, as canonical planet formation theories are not effective at such high radii. Recent studies, however, suggest that these enigmatic objects may be surrounded by disks of primordial material. Direct detection and characterization of these disks provides a new avenue for studying the formation of PMCs as well as their potential exomoon systems. Here we propose to survey 7 PMCs which show indirect evidence for the presence of such a disk. With ALMA we will image those disks and calculate disk masses to constrain PMC evolutionary paths as well as the amount of material available to form exomoons. We will also use 0.1" spatial resolution to resolve circumplanetary disks, measure their sizes and structures, search for CO (2-1) emission to measure Keplerian rotation and thereby dynamical masses for PMCs, and trace disk evolution by comparing disk morphology at different ages. This proposal is an important first step towards better understanding the formation of PMCs and exomoon systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
